g.text: in passing that CPFE correctly predicts the experimentally observed four-fold pile-up pattern, by constraining
slip to the applicable crystallographic slip systems. The contrasting, unphysical uniform distribution of pile-up
around the indent, predicted by an isotropic continuum finite element (FEM) model, is displayed in Figure B.1
(Appendix B in Supplementary Material) for comparison.
The residual elastic lattice rotations induced by nano-indentation
around and beneath indents (represented by rotation matrix
) were predicted by CPFE and compared with
HR-EBSD and Laue diffraction measurements (Laue data used from prior study for comparison
orientation of points in the unimplanted material, far from the indent (22–25
Laue and HR-EBSD respectively) was considered as the orientation of the un-deformed material,

. The indentation-induced change in crystal orientation from

accounts for the combined effect of sequential rotation about the X, Y and then
Z axis by the rotation angles
. Note, we use the common convention e.g.
viewed looking down the X-axis towards to origin (i.e. right handed rotations). The lattice rotations in Fig.
are plotted on virtual YZ slices, at different X positions, for both samples. For HR-EBSD, only rotation about
, is considered for one YZ slice through the indent centre. Rotations about the other two
axes are not considered as they may have been modified due to stress-relaxation during FIB-lift-out preparation.
HR-EBSD and Laue diffraction, respectively, have the advantage of high spatial resolution and high angular reso-
lution, and are compared with the CPFE predictions using the same colour and length-scales.
The Laue data and CPFE predictions of lattice rotations (Fig.
Interestingly, agreement is better for slices 5
m away from the indent centre (positions 1 and 3 in Fig.
disparity between CPFE and Laue data in position 2 is due to the presence of steep strain gradients and rapid vari-
ation of lattice rotation at the indent centre. In positions 1 and 3, rotations in the unimplanted sample, particularly
, are significantly larger than in the implanted sample. For quantitative analysis, line plots were extracted, for

implanted material. Also shown are the surface profiles predicted by CPFE.
